It was 103 degrees this past weekend in McAllen Texas which is the epicenter of this crisis.  And it is getting hotter. I hate to think what the situation will look like this summer if we fail to act.

If we fail @DHSgov will be faced with a choice: it will either have to stop its efforts to improve these brutal conditions on our border or it will have to raid other agencies vital to our national security.

People are upset about seeing pictures of people sleeping on concrete floors under mylar blankets.  I’ve been to these facilities and yes it will absolutely break your heart to see it.

Today we have significantly more people crossing our southern border – and because of who they are travelling with and where they are travelling from – each of those people causes significantly more strain on our system.
Unlike folks from Mexico these migrants cannot just be sent back home under U.S. law.  They remain in the U.S. often for months or even years as their cases work their way through the system.

Today we are seeing families – not just adults.  Last month nearly 64% of those who crossed our border illegally did so as members of a family unit coming namely from Guatemala El Salvador and Honduras.

Twenty years ago the vast majority of those crossing our border illegally were adult men from Mexico. In fact in FY 2000 98% of those caught at our border were Mexican.  Under U.S. law folks from Mexico can be immediately returned home by our Border Patrol.
